heading: Care About Your Craft
details: Why spend your life developing software unless you care about doing it well?

heading: Provide Options, Don’t Make Lame Excuses
details: Instead of excuses, provide options. Don’t say it can’t be done; explain what can be done.

heading: Be a Catalyst for Change
details: You can’t force change on people. Instead, show them how the future might be and help them participate in creating it.

heading: Make Quality a Requirements Issue
details: Involve your users in determining the project’s real quality requirements.

heading: Critically Analyze What You Read and Hear
details: Don’t be swayed by vendors, media hype, or dogma. Analyze information in terms of you and your project.

heading: DRY—Don’t Repeat Yourself
details: Every piece of knowledge must have a single, unambiguous, authoritative representation within a system.

heading: Eliminate Effects Between Unrelated Things
details: Design components that are self-contained, independent, and have a single, well-defined purpose.

heading: Use Tracer Bullets to Find the Target
details: Tracer bullets let you home in on your target by trying things and seeing how close they land.

heading: Program Close to the Problem Domain
details: Design and code in your user’s language.

heading: Iterate the Schedule with the Code
details: Use experience you gain as you implement to refine the project time scales.

heading: Use the Power of Command Shells
details: Use the shell when graphical user interfaces don’t cut it.

heading: Always Use Source Code Control
details: Source code control is a time machine for your work—you can go back.

heading: Don’t Panic When Debugging
details: Take a deep breath and THINK! about what could be causing the bug.

heading: Don’t Assume It—Prove It
details: Prove your assumptions in the actual environment—with real data and boundary conditions.

heading: Write Code That Writes Code
details: Code generators increase your productivity and help avoid duplication.

heading: Design with Contracts
details: Use contracts to document and verify that code does no more and no less than it claims to do.

heading: Use Assertions to Prevent the Impossible
details: Assertions validate your assumptions. Use them to protect your code from an uncertain world.

heading: Finish What You Start
details: Where possible, the routine or object that allocates a resource should be responsible for deallocating it.

heading: Configure, Don’t Integrate
details: Implement technology choices for an application as configuration options, not through integration or engineering.

heading: Analyze Workflow to Improve Concurrency
details: Exploit concurrency in your user’s workflow.

heading: Always Design for Concurrency
details: Allow for concurrency, and you’ll design cleaner interfaces with fewer assumptions.

heading: Use Blackboards to Coordinate Workflow
details: Use blackboards to coordinate disparate facts and agents, while maintaining independence and isolation among participants.

heading: Estimate the Order of Your Algorithms
details: Get a feel for how long things are likely to take before you write code.

heading: Refactor Early, Refactor Often
details: Just as you might weed and rearrange a garden, rewrite, rework, and re-architect code when it needs it. Fix the root of the problem.

heading: Test Your Software, or Your Users Will
details: Test ruthlessly. Don’t make your users find bugs for you.

heading: Don’t Gather Requirements—Dig for Them
details: Requirements rarely lie on the surface. They’re buried deep beneath layers of assumptions, misconceptions, and politics.

heading: Abstractions Live Longer than Details
details: Invest in the abstraction, not the implementation. Abstractions can survive the barrage of changes from different implementations and new technologies.

heading: Don’t Think Outside the Box—Find the Box
details: When faced with an impossible problem, identify the real constraints. Ask yourself: “Does it have to be done this way? Does it have to be done at all?”

heading: Some Things Are Better Done than Described
details: Don’t fall into the specification spiral—at some point you need to start coding.

heading: Costly Tools Don’t Produce Better Designs
details: Beware of vendor hype, industry dogma, and the aura of the price tag. Judge tools on their merits.

heading: Don’t Use Manual Procedures
details: A shell script or batch file will execute the same instructions, in the same order, time after time.

heading: Coding Ain’t Done ‘Til All the Tests Run
details: ‘Nuff said.

heading: Test State Coverage, Not Code Coverage
details: Identify and test significant program states. Just testing lines of code isn’t enough.

heading: English is Just a Programming Language
details: Write documents as you would write code: honor the DRY principle, use metadata, MVC, automatic generation, and so on.

heading: Gently Exceed Your Users’ Expectations
details: Come to understand your users’ expectations, then deliver just that little bit more.

heading: Think! About Your Work
details: Turn off the autopilot and take control. Constantly critique and appraise your work.

heading: Don’t Live with Broken Windows
details: Fix bad designs, wrong decisions, and poor code when you see them.

heading: Remember the Big Picture
details: Don’t get so engrossed in the details that you forget to check what’s happening around you.

heading: Invest Regularly in Your Knowledge Portfolio
details: Make learning a habit.

heading: It’s Both What You Say and the Way You Say It
details: There’s no point in having great ideas if you don’t communicate them effectively.

heading: Make It Easy to Reuse
details: If it’s easy to reuse, people will. Create an environment that supports reuse.

heading: There Are No Final Decisions
details: No decision is cast in stone. Instead, consider each as being written in the sand at the beach, and plan for change.

heading: Prototype to Learn
details: Prototyping is a learning experience. Its value lies not in the code you produce, but in the lessons you learn.

heading: Estimate to Avoid Surprises
details: Estimate before you start. You’ll spot potential problems up front.

heading: Keep Knowledge in Plain Text
details: Plain text won’t become obsolete. It helps leverage your work and simplifies debugging and testing.

heading: Use a Single Editor Well
details: The editor should be an extension of your hand; make sure your editor is configurable, extensible, and programmable.

heading: Fix the Problem, Not the Blame
details: It doesn’t really matter whether the bug is your fault or someone else’s—it is still your problem, and it still needs to be fixed.

heading: “select” Isn’t Broken
details: It is rare to find a bug in the OS or the compiler, or even a third-party product or library. The bug is most likely in the application.

heading: Learn a Text Manipulation Language
details: You spend a large part of each day working with text. Why not have the computer do some of it for you?

heading: You Can’t Write Perfect Software
details: Software can’t be perfect. Protect your code and users from the inevitable errors.

heading: Crash Early
details: A dead program normally does a lot less damage than a crippled one.

heading: Use Exceptions for Exceptional Problems
details: Exceptions can suffer from all the readability and maintainability problems of classic spaghetti code. Reserve exceptions for exceptional things.

heading: Minimize Coupling Between Modules
details: Avoid coupling by writing “shy” code and applying the Law of Demeter.

heading: Put Abstractions in Code, Details in Metadata
details: Program for the general case, and put the specifics outside the compiled code base.

heading: Design Using Services
details: Design in terms of services—independent, concurrent objects behind well-defined, consistent interfaces.

heading: Separate Views from Models
details: Gain flexibility at low cost by designing your application in terms of models and views.

heading: Don’t Program by Coincidence
details: Rely only on reliable things. Beware of accidental complexity, and don’t confuse a happy coincidence with a purposeful plan.

heading: Test Your Estimates
details: Mathematical analysis of algorithms doesn’t tell you everything. Try timing your code in its target environment.

heading: Design to Test
details: Start thinking about testing before you write a line of code.

heading: Don’t Use Wizard Code You Don’t Understand
details: Wizards can generate reams of code. Make sure you understand all of it before you incorporate it into your project.

heading: Work with a User to Think Like a User
details: It’s the best way to gain insight into how the system will really be used.

heading: Use a Project Glossary
details: Create and maintain a single source of all the specific terms and vocabulary for a project.

heading: Start When You’re Ready
details: You’ve been building experience all your life. Don’t ignore niggling doubts.

heading: Don’t Be a Slave to Formal Methods
details: Don’t blindly adopt any technique without putting it into the context of your development practices and capabilities.

heading: Organize Teams Around Functionality
details: Don’t separate designers from coders, testers from data modelers. Build teams the way you build code.

heading: Test Early. Test Often. Test Automatically.
details: Tests that run with every build are much more effective than test plans that sit on a shelf.

heading: Use Saboteurs to Test Your Testing
details: Introduce bugs on purpose in a separate copy of the source to verify that testing will catch them.

heading: Find Bugs Once
details: Once a human tester finds a bug, it should be the last time a human tester finds that bug. Automatic tests should check for it from then on.

heading: Build Documentation In, Don’t Bolt It On
details: Documentation created separately from code is less likely to be correct and up to date.

heading: Sign Your Work
details: Craftsmen of an earlier age were proud to sign their work. You should be, too.
